If `f` and `g` are continuous on `[a, b]`, `a < b`, `f x ‚â§ g x` on this interval, and
`f c < g c` at some point `c ‚àà [a, b]`, then `‚à´ x in a..b, f x < ‚à´ x in a..b, g x`.

type:
‚àÄ {f g : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} {a b : ‚Ñù},
  a < b ‚Üí
    ContinuousOn f (Set.Icc a b) ‚Üí
      ContinuousOn g (Set.Icc a b) ‚Üí
        (‚àÄ x ‚àà Set.Ioc a b, f x ‚â§ g x) ‚Üí
          (‚àÉ c ‚àà Set.Icc a b, f c < g c) ‚Üí ‚à´ (x : ‚Ñù) in a..b, f x < ‚à´ (x : ‚Ñù) in a..b, g x
name: intervalIntegral.integral_lt_integral_of_continuousOn_of_le_of_exists_lt
docString:
If `f` and `g` are continuous on `[a, b]`, `a < b`, `f x ‚â§ g x` on this interval, and
`f c < g c` at some point `c ‚àà [a, b]`, then `‚à´ x in a..b, f x < ‚à´ x in a..b, g x`.

For measurable functions $f, g : \alpha \to \mathbb{R} \cup \{+\infty\}$, and a measure $\mu$ on $\alpha$, if $p, q > 0$ satisfy $\frac{1}{p} + \frac{1}{q} = 1$, then $\int_\alpha |f(x) g(x)| d\mu \leq \left(\int_\alpha |f(x)|^p d\mu\right)^\frac{1}{p} \left(\int_\alpha |g(x)|^q d\mu\right)^\frac{1}{q}$.

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} [inst : MeasurableSpace Œ±] (Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure Œ±) {p q : ‚Ñù},
  p.IsConjExponent q ‚Üí
    ‚àÄ {f g : Œ± ‚Üí ENNReal},
      AEMeasurable f Œº ‚Üí
        AEMeasurable g Œº ‚Üí
          ‚à´‚Åª (a : Œ±), (f * g) a ‚àÇŒº ‚â§ (‚à´‚Åª (a : Œ±), f a ^ p ‚àÇŒº) ^ (1 / p) * (‚à´‚Åª (a : Œ±), g a ^ q ‚àÇŒº) ^ (1 / q)
name: ENNReal.lintegral_mul_le_Lp_mul_Lq
docString: For measurable functions $f, g : \alpha \to \mathbb{R} \cup \{+\infty\}$, and a measure $\mu$ on $\alpha$, if $p, q > 0$ satisfy $\frac{1}{p} + \frac{1}{q} = 1$, then $\int_\alpha |f(x) g(x)| d\mu \leq \left(\int_\alpha |f(x)|^p d\mu\right)^\frac{1}{p} \left(\int_\alpha |g(x)|^q d\mu\right)^\frac{1}{q}$.

The theorem states that if `f` and `g` are two real-valued functions that are continuous on a closed interval `[a, b]` where `a` is less than `b`, and for every `x` in the open interval `(a, b]`, `f(x)` is less than or equal to `g(x)`, and if there exists a point `c` in `[a, b]` such that `f(c)` is strictly less than `g(c)`, then the integral of `f` from `a` to `b` is strictly less than the integral of `g` from `a` to `b`. In mathematical terms, if $f$ and $g$ are continuous on $[a, b]$, $a < b$, $f(x) \leq g(x)$ on $(a, b]$, and $f(c) < g(c)$ for some $c \in [a, b]$, then $\int_{a}^{b} f(x) dx < \int_{a}^{b} g(x) dx$.

type:
‚àÄ {f g : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} {a b : ‚Ñù},
  a < b ‚Üí
    ContinuousOn f (Set.Icc a b) ‚Üí
      ContinuousOn g (Set.Icc a b) ‚Üí
        (‚àÄ x ‚àà Set.Ioc a b, f x ‚â§ g x) ‚Üí
          (‚àÉ c ‚àà Set.Icc a b, f c < g c) ‚Üí ‚à´ (x : ‚Ñù) in a..b, f x < ‚à´ (x : ‚Ñù) in a..b, g x
name: intervalIntegral.integral_lt_integral_of_continuousOn_of_le_of_exists_lt
docString: The theorem states that if `f` and `g` are two real-valued functions that are continuous on a closed interval `[a, b]` where `a` is less than `b`, and for every `x` in the open interval `(a, b]`, `f(x)` is less than or equal to `g(x)`, and if there exists a point `c` in `[a, b]` such that `f(c)` is strictly less than `g(c)`, then the integral of `f` from `a` to `b` is strictly less than the integral of `g` from `a` to `b`. In mathematical terms, if $f$ and $g$ are continuous on $[a, b]$, $a < b$, $f(x) \leq g(x)$ on $(a, b]$, and $f(c) < g(c)$ for some $c \in [a, b]$, then $\int_{a}^{b} f(x) dx < \int_{a}^{b} g(x) dx$.

A function on `[a, b]` with the norm of the derivative within `[a, b]`
bounded by `C` satisfies `‚Äñf x - f a‚Äñ ‚â§ C * (x - a)`, `HasDerivWithinAt`
version.

type: ‚àÄ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E] {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí E} {a b : ‚Ñù} {f' : ‚Ñù ‚Üí E} {C : ‚Ñù},   (‚àÄ x ‚àà Icc a b, HasDerivWithinAt f (f' x) (Icc a b) x) ‚Üí     (‚àÄ x ‚àà Ico a b, ‚Äñf' x‚Äñ ‚â§ C) ‚Üí ‚àÄ x ‚àà Icc a b, ‚Äñf x - f a‚Äñ ‚â§ C * (x - a)
statement:
theorem norm_image_sub_le_of_norm_deriv_le_segment' :
    ‚àÄ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E] {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí E} {a b : ‚Ñù} {f' : ‚Ñù ‚Üí E}
      {C : ‚Ñù},
      (‚àÄ x ‚àà Set.Icc a b, HasDerivWithinAt f (f' x) (Set.Icc a b) x) ‚Üí
        (‚àÄ x ‚àà Set.Ico a b, ‚Äñf' x‚Äñ ‚â§ C) ‚Üí ‚àÄ x ‚àà Set.Icc a b, ‚Äñf x - f a‚Äñ ‚â§ C * (x - a) :=
  by sorry
name: norm_image_sub_le_of_norm_deriv_le_segment'
docString:
A function on `[a, b]` with the norm of the derivative within `[a, b]`
bounded by `C` satisfies `‚Äñf x - f a‚Äñ ‚â§ C * (x - a)`, `HasDerivWithinAt`
version.
description: This theorem states that given a function `f` which maps real numbers to a normed additive commutative group `E`, and a real-valued function `f'` that represents the derivative of `f`, if `f` has a derivative `f'` within the closed interval `[a, b]` for all `x` in `[a, b]` and the norm of `f'` within the half-open interval `[a, b)` is bounded by a real number `C`, then for all `x` in `[a, b]`, the norm of the difference between `f(x)` and `f(a)` is less than or equal to `C` times the difference between `x` and `a`. In simpler terms, the theorem provides a bound on the change in the function `f` in terms of the maximum allowed rate of change (`C`) and the distance from `a` as per the Mean Value Theorem.
concise-description: If a real-valued function `f` with derivative `f'` on the interval `[a, b]` satisfies `‚àÄx‚àà[a,b]. ‚à•f'(x)‚à• ‚â§ C` and `f` is differentiable on `[a, b]`, then `‚à•f(x) - f(a)‚à• ‚â§ C * (x - a)` for all `x ‚àà [a, b]`.

For any two points in a topological space and a bounded, continuous function to a semi-normed additive commutative group, the image distance is less than or equal to twice the function's norm.

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u} {Œ≤ : Type v} [inst : TopologicalSpace Œ±] [inst_1 : SeminormedAddCommGroup Œ≤]
  (f : BoundedContinuousFunction Œ± Œ≤) (x y : Œ±), dist (f x) (f y) ‚â§ 2 * ‚Äñf‚Äñ
statement:
theorem BoundedContinuousFunction.dist_le_two_norm :
    ‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u} {Œ≤ : Type v} [inst : TopologicalSpace Œ±] [inst_1 : SeminormedAddCommGroup Œ≤]
      (f : BoundedContinuousFunction Œ± Œ≤) (x y : Œ±), dist (f x) (f y) ‚â§ 2 * ‚Äñf‚Äñ :=
  by sorry
name: BoundedContinuousFunction.dist_le_two_norm
docString: Distance between the images of any two points is at most twice the norm of the function.
description: This theorem states that for any two points in a topological space, the distance between their images under a bounded continuous function (which maps to a semi-normed additive commutative group) is at most twice the norm of that function. This provides a constraint on the maximum change in value that can be induced by such a function, given its norm.
concise-description: For any two points in a topological space and a bounded, continuous function to a semi-normed additive commutative group, the image distance is less than or equal to twice the function's norm.

If `f` is continuous on the circle `|z - c| = R`, `R > 0`, the `‚Äñf z‚Äñ` is less than or equal to
`C : ‚Ñù` on this circle, and this norm is strictly less than `C` at some point `z` of the circle,
then `‚Äñ‚àÆ z in C(c, R), f z‚Äñ < 2 * œÄ * R * C`.

type:
‚àÄ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚ÑÇ E] {f : ‚ÑÇ ‚Üí E} {c : ‚ÑÇ} {R C : ‚Ñù},
  0 < R ‚Üí
    ContinuousOn f (Metric.sphere c R) ‚Üí
      (‚àÄ z ‚àà Metric.sphere c R, ‚Äñf z‚Äñ ‚â§ C) ‚Üí
        (‚àÉ z ‚àà Metric.sphere c R, ‚Äñf z‚Äñ < C) ‚Üí ‚Äñ‚àÆ (z : ‚ÑÇ) in C(c, R), f z‚Äñ < 2 * Real.pi * R * C
name: circleIntegral.norm_integral_lt_of_norm_le_const_of_lt
docString:
If `f` is continuous on the circle `|z - c| = R`, `R > 0`, the `‚Äñf z‚Äñ` is less than or equal to
`C : ‚Ñù` on this circle, and this norm is strictly less than `C` at some point `z` of the circle,
then `‚Äñ‚àÆ z in C(c, R), f z‚Äñ < 2 * œÄ * R * C`.

For any continuous linear map $f$ from normed vector space $E$ over a nontrivially normed field $\mathbb{K}$ to normed vector space $F$ over a nontrivially normed field $\mathbb{K}_2$, the norm of $f(x)$ with respect to $F$ is less than or equal to the operator norm of $f$ times the norm of $x$ with respect to $E$, for all $x$ in $E$ with norm less than or equal to 1.

type:
‚àÄ {ùïú : Type u_1} {ùïú‚ÇÇ : Type u_2} {E : Type u_4} {F : Type u_6} [inst : SeminormedAddCommGroup E]
  [inst_1 : SeminormedAddCommGroup F] [inst_2 : NontriviallyNormedField ùïú] [inst_3 : NontriviallyNormedField ùïú‚ÇÇ]
  [inst_4 : NormedSpace ùïú E] [inst_5 : NormedSpace ùïú‚ÇÇ F] {œÉ‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ : ùïú ‚Üí+* ùïú‚ÇÇ} [inst_6 : RingHomIsometric œÉ‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ]
  (f : E ‚ÜíSL[œÉ‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇ] F) (x : E), ‚Äñx‚Äñ ‚â§ 1 ‚Üí ‚Äñf x‚Äñ ‚â§ ‚Äñf‚Äñ
name: ContinuousLinearMap.unit_le_opNorm
docString: For any continuous linear map $f$ from normed vector space $E$ over a nontrivially normed field $\mathbb{K}$ to normed vector space $F$ over a nontrivially normed field $\mathbb{K}_2$, the norm of $f(x)$ with respect to $F$ is less than or equal to the operator norm of $f$ times the norm of $x$ with respect to $E$, for all $x$ in $E$ with norm less than or equal to 1.

The "Fundamental theorem of calculus-2" states: Suppose `f` is a function from real numbers to type `E` (where `E` has a normed addition group structure, normed space structure over real numbers, and is a complete space). Now, if `f` is continuous on the closed interval `[a, b]` (where `a` is less than or equal to `b`) and has a right derivative `f'` at every point `x` in the open interval `(a, b)`, and if `f'` is interval integrable on the interval `[a, b]` with respect to the Lebesgue measure, then the integral of `f'` from `a` to `b` equals `f(b) - f(a)`. This implies that the area under the curve of the derivative function `f'` between `a` and `b` equals the difference in function values of `f` at `b` and `a`.

type:
‚àÄ {E : Type u_3} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {f f' : ‚Ñù ‚Üí E}
  {a b : ‚Ñù},
  a ‚â§ b ‚Üí
    ContinuousOn f (Set.Icc a b) ‚Üí
      (‚àÄ x ‚àà Set.Ioo a b, HasDerivWithinAt f (f' x) (Set.Ioi x) x) ‚Üí
        IntervalIntegrable f' MeasureTheory.volume a b ‚Üí ‚à´ (y : ‚Ñù) in a..b, f' y = f b - f a
name: intervalIntegral.integral_eq_sub_of_hasDeriv_right_of_le
docString: The "Fundamental theorem of calculus-2" states: Suppose `f` is a function from real numbers to type `E` (where `E` has a normed addition group structure, normed space structure over real numbers, and is a complete space). Now, if `f` is continuous on the closed interval `[a, b]` (where `a` is less than or equal to `b`) and has a right derivative `f'` at every point `x` in the open interval `(a, b)`, and if `f'` is interval integrable on the interval `[a, b]` with respect to the Lebesgue measure, then the integral of `f'` from `a` to `b` equals `f(b) - f(a)`. This implies that the area under the curve of the derivative function `f'` between `a` and `b` equals the difference in function values of `f` at `b` and `a`.

General fencing theorem for continuous functions with an estimate on the norm of the derivative.
Let `f` and `B` be continuous functions on `[a, b]` such that

* `‚Äñf a‚Äñ ‚â§ B a`;
* `f` and `B` have right derivatives `f'` and `B'` respectively at every point of `[a, b)`;
* we have `‚Äñf' x‚Äñ ‚â§ B x` everywhere on `[a, b)`.

Then `‚Äñf x‚Äñ ‚â§ B x` everywhere on `[a, b]`. We use one-sided derivatives in the assumptions
to make this theorem work for piecewise differentiable functions.

type: ‚àÄ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E] {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí E} {a b : ‚Ñù} {f' : ‚Ñù ‚Üí E},   ContinuousOn f (Icc a b) ‚Üí     (‚àÄ x ‚àà Ico a b, HasDerivWithinAt f (f' x) (Ici x) x) ‚Üí       ‚àÄ {B B' : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù},         ‚Äñf a‚Äñ ‚â§ B a ‚Üí           ContinuousOn B (Icc a b) ‚Üí             (‚àÄ x ‚àà Ico a b, HasDerivWithinAt B (B' x) (Ici x) x) ‚Üí               (‚àÄ x ‚àà Ico a b, ‚Äñf' x‚Äñ ‚â§ B' x) ‚Üí ‚àÄ ‚¶Éx : ‚Ñù‚¶Ñ, x ‚àà Icc a b ‚Üí ‚Äñf x‚Äñ ‚â§ B x
statement:
theorem image_norm_le_of_norm_deriv_right_le_deriv_boundary' :
    ‚àÄ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E] {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí E} {a b : ‚Ñù} {f' : ‚Ñù ‚Üí E},
      ContinuousOn f (Set.Icc a b) ‚Üí
        (‚àÄ x ‚àà Set.Ico a b, HasDerivWithinAt f (f' x) (Set.Ici x) x) ‚Üí
          ‚àÄ {B B' : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù},
            ‚Äñf a‚Äñ ‚â§ B a ‚Üí
              ContinuousOn B (Set.Icc a b) ‚Üí
                (‚àÄ x ‚àà Set.Ico a b, HasDerivWithinAt B (B' x) (Set.Ici x) x) ‚Üí
                  (‚àÄ x ‚àà Set.Ico a b, ‚Äñf' x‚Äñ ‚â§ B' x) ‚Üí ‚àÄ ‚¶Éx : ‚Ñù‚¶Ñ, x ‚àà Set.Icc a b ‚Üí ‚Äñf x‚Äñ ‚â§ B x :=
  by sorry
name: image_norm_le_of_norm_deriv_right_le_deriv_boundary'
docString:
General fencing theorem for continuous functions with an estimate on the norm of the derivative.
Let `f` and `B` be continuous functions on `[a, b]` such that

* `‚Äñf a‚Äñ ‚â§ B a`;
* `f` and `B` have right derivatives `f'` and `B'` respectively at every point of `[a, b)`;
* we have `‚Äñf' x‚Äñ ‚â§ B x` everywhere on `[a, b)`.

Then `‚Äñf x‚Äñ ‚â§ B x` everywhere on `[a, b]`. We use one-sided derivatives in the assumptions
to make this theorem work for piecewise differentiable functions.
description: The theorem, known as the general fencing theorem for continuous functions with an estimate on the norm of the derivative, states that given two continuous functions `f` and `B` on a closed interval `[a, b]`, if the norm of `f` at `a` is less than or equal to `B` at `a`, `f` and `B` have right derivatives `f'` and `B'` respectively at every point in the half-open interval `[a, b)`, and the norm of `f'` at any point in `[a, b)` is less than or equal to `B` at that point, then the norm of `f` at any point in `[a, b]` is less than or equal to `B` at that point. This theorem allows for piecewise differentiable functions as it uses one-sided derivatives in the assumptions.
concise-description: If two continuous functions on a closed interval have matching norms at an interior point and the norm of one's derivative is less than or equal to that of the other at each interior point, then the norm of the first function is less than or equal to the norm of the second function at every point in the interval.

Given a seminormed add commutative group `Œ≤` and a function `f` from type `Œ≥` to `Œ≤`, if the norm of `f(x)` is bounded by `C` for all `x` in `Œ≥`, then the norm of `f(x) - f(y)` is less than or equal to `2*C` for all `x` and `y` in `Œ≥`.

type:
‚àÄ {Œ≤ : Type v} {Œ≥ : Type w} [inst : SeminormedAddCommGroup Œ≤] {f : Œ≥ ‚Üí Œ≤} {C : ‚Ñù},
  (‚àÄ (x : Œ≥), ‚Äñf x‚Äñ ‚â§ C) ‚Üí ‚àÄ (x y : Œ≥), dist (f x) (f y) ‚â§ 2 * C
statement:
theorem BoundedContinuousFunction.dist_le_two_norm' :
    ‚àÄ {Œ≤ : Type v} {Œ≥ : Type w} [inst : SeminormedAddCommGroup Œ≤] {f : Œ≥ ‚Üí Œ≤} {C : ‚Ñù},
      (‚àÄ (x : Œ≥), ‚Äñf x‚Äñ ‚â§ C) ‚Üí ‚àÄ (x y : Œ≥), dist (f x) (f y) ‚â§ 2 * C :=
  by sorry
name: BoundedContinuousFunction.dist_le_two_norm'
description: This theorem states that for any type `Œ≤` which is a seminormed add commutative group and a function `f` from type `Œ≥` to `Œ≤`, given a real number `C`, if the norm of `f(x)` is less than or equal to `C` for all `x` of type `Œ≥`, then the distance between `f(x)` and `f(y)` for any `x` and `y` of type `Œ≥` is less than or equal to `2*C`. It essentially establishes a bound on the distance between the image points of any two elements under a function in terms of a constant `C` that bounds the norm of the function.
concise-description: Given a seminormed add commutative group `Œ≤` and a function `f` from type `Œ≥` to `Œ≤`, if the norm of `f(x)` is bounded by `C` for all `x` in `Œ≥`, then the norm of `f(x) - f(y)` is less than or equal to `2*C` for all `x` and `y` in `Œ≥`.

The uniform norm of the Fourier integral of `f` is bounded by the `L¬π` norm of `f`.

type:
‚àÄ {ùïú : Type u_1} [inst : CommRing ùïú] {V : Type u_2} [inst_1 : AddCommGroup V] [inst_2 : Module ùïú V]
  [inst_3 : MeasurableSpace V] {W : Type u_3} [inst_4 : AddCommGroup W] [inst_5 : Module ùïú W] {E : Type u_4}
  [inst_6 : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_7 : NormedSpace ‚ÑÇ E] (e : Multiplicative ùïú ‚Üí* ‚Ü•circle)
  (Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure V) (L : V ‚Üí‚Çó[ùïú] W ‚Üí‚Çó[ùïú] ùïú) (f : V ‚Üí E) (w : W),
  ‚ÄñVectorFourier.fourierIntegral e Œº L f w‚Äñ ‚â§ ‚à´ (v : V), ‚Äñf v‚Äñ ‚àÇŒº
name: VectorFourier.norm_fourierIntegral_le_integral_norm
docString: The uniform norm of the Fourier integral of `f` is bounded by the `L¬π` norm of `f`.

If `f` is a continuous function on the closed interval `[a, b]` with `f(a) ‚â§ B(a)`, `B` is continuous on `[a, b]` with a right derivative `B'` on `[a, b)`, the right-limit inferiors of `(f(z) - f(x)) / (z - x)` are bounded above by a function `f'`, and `f(x) = B(x)` implies `f'(x) < B'(x)`, then `f(x) ‚â§ B(x)` for all `x` in `[a, b]`.

type:
‚àÄ {f f' : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} {a b : ‚Ñù},
  ContinuousOn f (Set.Icc a b) ‚Üí
    (‚àÄ x ‚àà Set.Ico a b, ‚àÄ (r : ‚Ñù), f' x < r ‚Üí ‚àÉ·∂† (z : ‚Ñù) in nhdsWithin x (Set.Ioi x), slope f x z < r) ‚Üí
      ‚àÄ {B B' : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù},
        f a ‚â§ B a ‚Üí
          ContinuousOn B (Set.Icc a b) ‚Üí
            (‚àÄ x ‚àà Set.Ico a b, HasDerivWithinAt B (B' x) (Set.Ici x) x) ‚Üí
              (‚àÄ x ‚àà Set.Ico a b, f x = B x ‚Üí f' x < B' x) ‚Üí ‚àÄ ‚¶Éx : ‚Ñù‚¶Ñ, x ‚àà Set.Icc a b ‚Üí f x ‚â§ B x
name: image_le_of_liminf_slope_right_lt_deriv_boundary'
docString: If `f` is a continuous function on the closed interval `[a, b]` with `f(a) ‚â§ B(a)`, `B` is continuous on `[a, b]` with a right derivative `B'` on `[a, b)`, the right-limit inferiors of `(f(z) - f(x)) / (z - x)` are bounded above by a function `f'`, and `f(x) = B(x)` implies `f'(x) < B'(x)`, then `f(x) ‚â§ B(x)` for all `x` in `[a, b]`.

The theorem `norm_image_sub_le_of_norm_deriv_le_segment_01` states that, for any real-valued function `f` defined on the closed interval `[0, 1]`, if `f` is differentiable on this interval and the norm of its derivative within this interval is bounded by a real number `C`, then the norm of the difference between the function values at the endpoints of the interval (i.e., `f(1) - f(0)`) is less than or equal to `C`. This is a formal statement of the property that the difference between the function values at the endpoints of the interval is controlled by the maximal rate of change of the function on the interval.

type:
‚àÄ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E] {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí E} {C : ‚Ñù},
  DifferentiableOn ‚Ñù f (Set.Icc 0 1) ‚Üí (‚àÄ x ‚àà Set.Ico 0 1, ‚ÄñderivWithin f (Set.Icc 0 1) x‚Äñ ‚â§ C) ‚Üí ‚Äñf 1 - f 0‚Äñ ‚â§ C
name: norm_image_sub_le_of_norm_deriv_le_segment_01
docString: The theorem `norm_image_sub_le_of_norm_deriv_le_segment_01` states that, for any real-valued function `f` defined on the closed interval `[0, 1]`, if `f` is differentiable on this interval and the norm of its derivative within this interval is bounded by a real number `C`, then the norm of the difference between the function values at the endpoints of the interval (i.e., `f(1) - f(0)`) is less than or equal to `C`. This is a formal statement of the property that the difference between the function values at the endpoints of the interval is controlled by the maximal rate of change of the function on the interval.

A function on `[0, 1]` with the norm of the derivative within `[0, 1]`
bounded by `C` satisfies `‚Äñf 1 - f 0‚Äñ ‚â§ C`, `HasDerivWithinAt`
version.

type: ‚àÄ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E] {f f' : ‚Ñù ‚Üí E} {C : ‚Ñù},   (‚àÄ x ‚àà Icc 0 1, HasDerivWithinAt f (f' x) (Icc 0 1) x) ‚Üí (‚àÄ x ‚àà Ico 0 1, ‚Äñf' x‚Äñ ‚â§ C) ‚Üí ‚Äñf 1 - f 0‚Äñ ‚â§ C
statement:
theorem norm_image_sub_le_of_norm_deriv_le_segment_01' :
    ‚àÄ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E] {f f' : ‚Ñù ‚Üí E} {C : ‚Ñù},
      (‚àÄ x ‚àà Set.Icc 0 1, HasDerivWithinAt f (f' x) (Set.Icc 0 1) x) ‚Üí
        (‚àÄ x ‚àà Set.Ico 0 1, ‚Äñf' x‚Äñ ‚â§ C) ‚Üí ‚Äñf 1 - f 0‚Äñ ‚â§ C :=
  by sorry
name: norm_image_sub_le_of_norm_deriv_le_segment_01'
docString:
A function on `[0, 1]` with the norm of the derivative within `[0, 1]`
bounded by `C` satisfies `‚Äñf 1 - f 0‚Äñ ‚â§ C`, `HasDerivWithinAt`
version.
description: This theorem states that for any function `f` from real numbers to a normed additive commutative group `E`, if the derivative of `f` exists within the closed interval `[0, 1]`, and the norm of the derivative within the half-open interval `[0, 1)` is bounded by a real number `C`, then the norm of the difference between `f(1)` and `f(0)` is less than or equal to `C`. In other words, if a function has its derivative's norm controlled by `C` in the interval from 0 to 1, then the change in function values between 0 and 1 is also controlled by `C`.
concise-description: If `f` is a real-valued differentiable function on the interval [0, 1] with the property that the norm of its derivative is bounded by `C` on [0, 1), then the norm of `f(1) - f(0)` is less than or equal to `C`.

If a complex function is differentiable in the open second quadrant, continuous on its closure, and its norm is bounded above by `A * exp(B * (abs z) ^ c)` on the open second quadrant and by a constant `C` on its boundary, then its norm is bounded above by `C` on the closed second quadrant.

type:
‚àÄ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚ÑÇ E] {C : ‚Ñù} {f : ‚ÑÇ ‚Üí E} {z : ‚ÑÇ},
  DiffContOnCl ‚ÑÇ f (Set.Iio 0 √ó‚ÑÇ Set.Ioi 0) ‚Üí
    (‚àÉ c < 2,
        ‚àÉ B,
          f =O[Bornology.cobounded ‚ÑÇ ‚äì Filter.principal (Set.Iio 0 √ó‚ÑÇ Set.Ioi 0)] fun z =>
            Real.exp (B * Complex.abs z ^ c)) ‚Üí
      (‚àÄ x ‚â§ 0, ‚Äñf ‚Üëx‚Äñ ‚â§ C) ‚Üí (‚àÄ (x : ‚Ñù), 0 ‚â§ x ‚Üí ‚Äñf (‚Üëx * Complex.I)‚Äñ ‚â§ C) ‚Üí z.re ‚â§ 0 ‚Üí 0 ‚â§ z.im ‚Üí ‚Äñf z‚Äñ ‚â§ C
statement:
theorem PhragmenLindelof.quadrant_II :
    ‚àÄ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚ÑÇ E] {C : ‚Ñù} {f : ‚ÑÇ ‚Üí E} {z : ‚ÑÇ},
      DiffContOnCl ‚ÑÇ f (Set.Iio 0 √ó‚ÑÇ Set.Ioi 0) ‚Üí
        (‚àÉ c < 2,
            ‚àÉ B,
              f =O[Bornology.cobounded ‚ÑÇ ‚äì Filter.principal (Set.Iio 0 √ó‚ÑÇ Set.Ioi 0)] fun z =>
                (B * Complex.abs z ^ c).exp) ‚Üí
          (‚àÄ x ‚â§ 0, ‚Äñf ‚Üëx‚Äñ ‚â§ C) ‚Üí (‚àÄ (x : ‚Ñù), 0 ‚â§ x ‚Üí ‚Äñf (‚Üëx * Complex.I)‚Äñ ‚â§ C) ‚Üí z.re ‚â§ 0 ‚Üí 0 ‚â§ z.im ‚Üí ‚Äñf z‚Äñ ‚â§ C :=
  by sorry
name: PhragmenLindelof.quadrant_II
description:
**Phragm√©n‚ÄìLindel√∂f Principle** in the second quadrant. 

Consider a complex function `f` satisfying the following conditions:

- It is differentiable in the open second quadrant and is continuous on its closure.
- The norm of `f(z)`, denoted `‚Äñf z‚Äñ`, is bounded from above by `A * exp(B * (abs z) ^ c)` on the open second quadrant for some `c < 2`.
- The norm of `f(z)` is bounded from above by a constant `C` on the boundary of the second quadrant.

Then the theorem states that if these conditions hold, the norm of `f(z)` is also bounded from above by the same constant `C` on the closed second quadrant. Here, the second quadrant refers to the set of complex numbers `z` with negative real part and positive imaginary part. 

The theorem is formalized with several Lean definitions, including intervals (`Set.Iio` and `Set.Ioi`), filters (`Bornology.cobounded` and `Filter.principal`), the complex absolute value (`Complex.abs`), and the imaginary unit (`Complex.I`). This theorem is a crucial result in complex analysis, particularly in the study of boundedness of analytic functions.
concise-description: If a complex function is differentiable in the open second quadrant, continuous on its closure, and its norm is bounded above by `A * exp(B * (abs z) ^ c)` on the open second quadrant and by a constant `C` on its boundary, then its norm is bounded above by `C` on the closed second quadrant.

Intermediate value theorem for two functions: if `f` and `g` are two continuous functions
on a preconnected space and `f a ‚â§ g a` and `g b ‚â§ f b`, then for some `x` we have `f x = g x`.

type:
‚àÄ {X : Type u} {Œ± : Type v} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_1 : LinearOrder Œ±] [inst_2 : TopologicalSpace Œ±]
  [inst_3 : OrderClosedTopology Œ±] [inst_4 : PreconnectedSpace X] {a b : X} {f g : X ‚Üí Œ±},
  Continuous f ‚Üí Continuous g ‚Üí f a ‚â§ g a ‚Üí g b ‚â§ f b ‚Üí ‚àÉ x, f x = g x
name: intermediate_value_univ‚ÇÇ
docString:
Intermediate value theorem for two functions: if `f` and `g` are two continuous functions
on a preconnected space and `f a ‚â§ g a` and `g b ‚â§ f b`, then for some `x` we have `f x = g x`.

If `f` and `g` are continuous real-valued functions on a closed interval `[a, b]` with `a < b`, `f(x) ‚â§ g(x)` for all `x ‚àà (a, b]`, and there exists a point `c ‚àà [a, b]` with `f(c) < g(c)`, then `‚à´[a,b] f(x) dx < ‚à´[a,b] g(x) dx`.

type:
‚àÄ {f g : ‚Ñù ‚Üí ‚Ñù} {a b : ‚Ñù},
  a < b ‚Üí
    ContinuousOn f (Set.Icc a b) ‚Üí
      ContinuousOn g (Set.Icc a b) ‚Üí
        (‚àÄ x ‚àà Set.Ioc a b, f x ‚â§ g x) ‚Üí
          (‚àÉ c ‚àà Set.Icc a b, f c < g c) ‚Üí ‚à´ (x : ‚Ñù) in a..b, f x < ‚à´ (x : ‚Ñù) in a..b, g x
name: intervalIntegral.integral_lt_integral_of_continuousOn_of_le_of_exists_lt
docString: If `f` and `g` are continuous real-valued functions on a closed interval `[a, b]` with `a < b`, `f(x) ‚â§ g(x)` for all `x ‚àà (a, b]`, and there exists a point `c ‚àà [a, b]` with `f(c) < g(c)`, then `‚à´[a,b] f(x) dx < ‚à´[a,b] g(x) dx`.

The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 2, states that for a function `f` mapping real numbers to a normed group with a normed real vector space structure and a complete metric space structure. Given two real numbers `a` and `b`, and a countable set `s`, if `f` is continuous on the closed interval from `a` to `b`, `f` has a derivative at every point in the open interval from `min(a,b)` to `max(a,b)` excluding the points in `s`, and the derivative of `f` is interval integrable over `a` to `b` with respect to the Lebesgue measure, then the integral over `a` to `b` of the derivative of `f` equals `f(b) - f(a)`. This version of the theorem does not require `f` to be differentiable on the points in `s`, making it a more general form. Another version of the theorem requires `f` to be right differentiable.

type:
‚àÄ {E : Type u} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] (f f' : ‚Ñù ‚Üí E)
  {a b : ‚Ñù} {s : Set ‚Ñù},
  s.Countable ‚Üí
    ContinuousOn f (Set.uIcc a b) ‚Üí
      (‚àÄ x ‚àà Set.Ioo (min a b) (max a b) \ s, HasDerivAt f (f' x) x) ‚Üí
        IntervalIntegrable f' MeasureTheory.volume a b ‚Üí ‚à´ (x : ‚Ñù) in a..b, f' x = f b - f a
name: MeasureTheory.integral_eq_of_hasDerivWithinAt_off_countable
docString: The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, Part 2, states that for a function `f` mapping real numbers to a normed group with a normed real vector space structure and a complete metric space structure. Given two real numbers `a` and `b`, and a countable set `s`, if `f` is continuous on the closed interval from `a` to `b`, `f` has a derivative at every point in the open interval from `min(a,b)` to `max(a,b)` excluding the points in `s`, and the derivative of `f` is interval integrable over `a` to `b` with respect to the Lebesgue measure, then the integral over `a` to `b` of the derivative of `f` equals `f(b) - f(a)`. This version of the theorem does not require `f` to be differentiable on the points in `s`, making it a more general form. Another version of the theorem requires `f` to be right differentiable.

A function on `[a, b]` with the norm of the derivative within `[a, b]`
bounded by `C` satisfies `‚Äñf x - f a‚Äñ ‚â§ C * (x - a)`, `derivWithin`
version.

type: ‚àÄ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E] {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí E} {a b C : ‚Ñù},   DifferentiableOn ‚Ñù f (Icc a b) ‚Üí     (‚àÄ x ‚àà Ico a b, ‚ÄñderivWithin f (Icc a b) x‚Äñ ‚â§ C) ‚Üí ‚àÄ x ‚àà Icc a b, ‚Äñf x - f a‚Äñ ‚â§ C * (x - a)
statement:
theorem norm_image_sub_le_of_norm_deriv_le_segment :
    ‚àÄ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E] {f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí E} {a b C : ‚Ñù},
      DifferentiableOn ‚Ñù f (Set.Icc a b) ‚Üí
        (‚àÄ x ‚àà Set.Ico a b, ‚ÄñderivWithin f (Set.Icc a b) x‚Äñ ‚â§ C) ‚Üí ‚àÄ x ‚àà Set.Icc a b, ‚Äñf x - f a‚Äñ ‚â§ C * (x - a) :=
  by sorry
name: norm_image_sub_le_of_norm_deriv_le_segment
docString:
A function on `[a, b]` with the norm of the derivative within `[a, b]`
bounded by `C` satisfies `‚Äñf x - f a‚Äñ ‚â§ C * (x - a)`, `derivWithin`
version.
description: The theorem `norm_image_sub_le_of_norm_deriv_le_segment` states that for a function `f` from reals (`‚Ñù`) to a normed additive commutative group (`E`), if the function `f` is differentiable on a closed interval `[a, b]` and the norm of the derivative of `f` within this interval is bounded by a real number `C`, then for any `x` in the interval `[a, b]`, the norm of the difference `f(x) - f(a)` is less than or equal to `C` times `(x - a)`. This theorem essentially provides a bound on the change in `f` in terms of the bound on its derivative.
concise-description: Given a real-valued, differentiable function `f` on a closed interval `[a, b]` with derivative norm `C`, the norm of `f(x) - f(a)` is bounded by `C * (x - a)` for all `x` in `[a, b]`.

For any compact topological space, the image distance of two points under a continuous function to a normed additive commutative group is less than or equal to twice the norm of the function.

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} {E : Type u_3} [inst : TopologicalSpace Œ±] [inst_1 : CompactSpace Œ±]
  [inst_2 : SeminormedAddCommGroup E] (f : C(Œ±, E)) (x y : Œ±), dist (f x) (f y) ‚â§ 2 * ‚Äñf‚Äñ
statement:
theorem ContinuousMap.dist_le_two_norm :
    ‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} {E : Type u_3} [inst : TopologicalSpace Œ±] [inst_1 : CompactSpace Œ±]
      [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup E] (f : C(Œ±, E)) (x y : Œ±), dist (f x) (f y) ‚â§ 2 * ‚Äñf‚Äñ :=
  by sorry
name: ContinuousMap.dist_le_two_norm
docString: Distance between the images of any two points is at most twice the norm of the function.
description: This theorem states that for any two points in a compact topological space, the distance between their images under a continuous function into a normed additive commutative group is at most twice the norm of the function. In other words, the distance stretched by the function is bounded by twice its norm.
concise-description: For any compact topological space, the image distance of two points under a continuous function to a normed additive commutative group is less than or equal to twice the norm of the function.

Shifting `f` by `(1 / (2 * ‚Äñw‚Äñ ^ 2)) ‚Ä¢ w` negates the integral in the Riemann-Lebesgue lemma.

type:
‚àÄ {E : Type u_1} {V : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚ÑÇ E] {f : V ‚Üí E}
  [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup V] [inst_3 : MeasurableSpace V] [inst_4 : BorelSpace V] [inst_5 : InnerProductSpace ‚Ñù V]
  [inst_6 : FiniteDimensional ‚Ñù V] {w : V},
  w ‚â† 0 ‚Üí
    ‚à´ (v : V), ‚Üë(Real.fourierChar (Multiplicative.ofAdd (-‚ü™v, w‚ü´_‚Ñù))) ‚Ä¢ f (v + (fun w => (1 / (2 * ‚Äñw‚Äñ ^ 2)) ‚Ä¢ w) w) =
      -‚à´ (v : V), ‚Üë(Real.fourierChar (Multiplicative.ofAdd (-‚ü™v, w‚ü´_‚Ñù))) ‚Ä¢ f v
name: fourier_integral_half_period_translate
docString: Shifting `f` by `(1 / (2 * ‚Äñw‚Äñ ^ 2)) ‚Ä¢ w` negates the integral in the Riemann-Lebesgue lemma.

If a function `f` is continuous on an open interval
and tends to the same value at its endpoints, then it has an extremum on this open interval.

type:
‚àÄ {X : Type u_1} {Y : Type u_2} [inst : ConditionallyCompleteLinearOrder X] [inst_1 : DenselyOrdered X]
  [inst_2 : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_3 : OrderTopology X] [inst_4 : LinearOrder Y] [inst_5 : TopologicalSpace Y]
  [inst_6 : OrderTopology Y] {f : X ‚Üí Y} {a b : X} {l : Y},
  a < b ‚Üí
    ContinuousOn f (Set.Ioo a b) ‚Üí
      Filter.Tendsto f (nhdsWithin a (Set.Ioi a)) (nhds l) ‚Üí
        Filter.Tendsto f (nhdsWithin b (Set.Iio b)) (nhds l) ‚Üí ‚àÉ c ‚àà Set.Ioo a b, IsExtrOn f (Set.Ioo a b) c
name: exists_isExtrOn_Ioo_of_tendsto
docString:
If a function `f` is continuous on an open interval
and tends to the same value at its endpoints, then it has an extremum on this open interval.

Fundamental theorem of calculus-2: If `f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí E` is continuous on `[a, b]` (where `a ‚â§ b`) and
has a derivative at `f' x` for all `x` in `(a, b)`, and `f'` is integrable on `[a, b]`, then
`‚à´ y in a..b, f' y` equals `f b - f a`.

type:
‚àÄ {E : Type u_3} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {f f' : ‚Ñù ‚Üí E}
  {a b : ‚Ñù},
  a ‚â§ b ‚Üí
    ContinuousOn f (Set.Icc a b) ‚Üí
      (‚àÄ x ‚àà Set.Ioo a b, HasDerivAt f (f' x) x) ‚Üí
        IntervalIntegrable f' MeasureTheory.volume a b ‚Üí ‚à´ (y : ‚Ñù) in a..b, f' y = f b - f a
name: intervalIntegral.integral_eq_sub_of_hasDerivAt_of_le
docString:
Fundamental theorem of calculus-2: If `f : ‚Ñù ‚Üí E` is continuous on `[a, b]` (where `a ‚â§ b`) and
has a derivative at `f' x` for all `x` in `(a, b)`, and `f'` is integrable on `[a, b]`, then
`‚à´ y in a..b, f' y` equals `f b - f a`.

If two functions are equal in the relevant interval, their interval integrals are also equal.

type:
‚àÄ {E : Type u_3} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E] {f g : ‚Ñù ‚Üí E} {Œº : MeasureTheory.Measure ‚Ñù}
  {a b : ‚Ñù}, Set.EqOn f g (Set.uIcc a b) ‚Üí ‚à´ (x : ‚Ñù) in a..b, f x ‚àÇŒº = ‚à´ (x : ‚Ñù) in a..b, g x ‚àÇŒº
name: intervalIntegral.integral_congr
docString: If two functions are equal in the relevant interval, their interval integrals are also equal.
